Fig. 1 (A) Activity pattern of the M1C1(A) catalyst in the CWAO of phenol; (B) Stability pattern of the M1C1(A) catalyst during seven consecutive reaction cycles (Reaction conditions: T, 423 K; P, 1.4 MPa; pO2, 0.9 MPa; wcat,wPhOH, 5). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Influence of catalyst composition on the CO2 yield (YCO2) in the CO oxidation (GHSV, 180,000 h−1; pC O=pO2 , 2.5 kPa) and in the CWAO of phenol (P, 1.4 MPa; pO2 , 0.9 MPa; wcat/wPhOH, 5) at 423 K (data taken from Tab. S1 of SI). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of “A” (black lines) and “B” (red lines) catalysts. Dotted lines show the main cerianite reflexes (JCPDS 34-394) with the relative Miller indices, while the Miller indices of the α-MnO2 (JCPDS 44-0141) and δ-MnO2 (JCPDS 18-0802) species are indicated in black and red, respectively (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM micrographs of the M1C1(B) (A, B), M1C1(A) (C, D) and M5C1(A) (E, F) samples at different magnification. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectra (A) and effect of composition on the surface Mn/Ce atomic ratio (XPS) of “A” and “B” catalysts (B). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effect of composition (A) and preparation method (B) on the TPR profiles of the untreated “A” and “B” catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of composition on: (A) percentage of Mn(II), Mn(III) and Mn(IV) atoms; (B) abundance of surface Mn(II) atoms and amount of Ce(IV) ions reduced at T≤723 K. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of composition (A) and preparation method (B) on the TPR profiles of catalysts pretreated in situ in O2 flow (673 K). Dotted lines show the profiles of the untreated samples (see Fig. 6 ). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (A) IR spectra of M5C1(A) (a), M1C1(A) (b) and M1C3(A) (c) in interaction with the CO-O2 mixture (pCO = pO2 , 25 mbar) for 30 min at 298 K; (B) IR spectra of the M5C1(A) catalyst in interaction with CO2 at increasing pressure (0-25 mbar, spectra a-o) compared with the spectrum obtained after 30 min of contact with the CO-O2 mixture (spectrum a’). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Effect of catalyst composition on: (A) the CO2 MnOx-site time-yield (styMnOx ); (B) the CO2 surface time-yield (ssty); (C) the fraction and (D) the abundance of surface Mn(II), Mn(III) and Mn(IV) atoms, respectively. Bare and ceria-promoted MnOx catalysts (0 ≤ χMn≤1) were prepared by redox-precipitation reactions of Mn(VII), Mn(II) and Ce(III) or Ce(IV) precursors in slightly acidic (pH, 4.5) or basic (pH, 8.0) environment to assess genesis, nature, and functionality of surface active sites. Both synthesis protocols yield nanostructured materials with large surface area and exposure of Mn sites, featuring high activity in the CO oxidation and the phenol wet-air-oxidation (CWAO) model reactions (T, 423 K). High oxide dispersion prompts an extensive incorporation of Mn(II) ions into ceria substitutional solid-solution structures, forming oxygen-vacancies with stronger oxidation activity than surface Mn(IV) sites. Basic structure-activity relationships indicate that the superior CO oxidation performance of the pristine α-MnO2 system relies on large exposure of very reducible Mn(IV) active sites, while O2-adsorption onto Mn(II)/O-vacancy active centres generates very reactive surface oxygen-species boosting the efficiency of composite MnCeOx catalysts in the CWAO of phenol. Keywords Manganese oxide catalysts Active sites CO oxidation Phenol wet air oxidation (CWAO) Structure-activity relationships Catalyst design 1 Introduction Since several decades, manganese oxides attract great attention as catalytic materials because of the Mn abundance on Earth, low cost, no significant toxicity, and performance comparable to noble-metal catalysts in several environmental, energy and green-chemistry reactions. In this respect, numerous studies evidenced a remarkable electro-catalytic activity of engineered MnOx materials in the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [1–4], which also show high performances in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [4–7]. Moreover, MnOx catalysts are quite efficient in the oxidative removal of CO [8–15] and VOC’s [16–19], the selective reduction of NOx (SCR) [8,20,21], the soot oxidation [22] and the green selective oxidation of organic substrates [23–25]. Further, remarkable promoting effects of ceria [14,19,23,26–40] and iron oxides [23,41,42] on the functionality of the MnOx phase have been documented. Thus, innovative synthesis routes were adopted for tailoring nanocomposite catalysts very active in gas and liquid phase reactions [14,23,26–42]. Strongly oxidizing Mn(IV) sites generally account for the reactivity of the unpromoted MnOx catalysts although phase structure [1–10,16–22,25,43], crystal facets [5,10,16,31,44], texture and morphology [1,5,12,14,17,18,21] and dopants [8,11,14,19,21,23,24,29–48] affect type and availability of surface active sites. Then, it has been claimed that Mn(III) centres could be crucial owing to distorted coordination geometry and high reactivity of d4 ions [2,15,37]. Moreover, synergistic interactions of the oxide phases determine the peculiar physico-chemical properties and the activity pattern of composite systems [26,41,42]. In particular, both computational and experimental studies addressed the interactions of ceria with Mn atoms to ascertain the chemistry behind the reactivity of Mn-doped ceria systems [45,30–48]. Although this is generally ascribed to high reducibility of surface Mn(IV) atoms in interaction with ceria carrier [12,14,19,23,27,30–34,37–40,45–47], the role of surface Mn(III) and Mn(II) centres on the functionality of MnCeOx systems remains still matter of debate [28,35–37,40,48]. In addition, structural defects and oxygen-vacancies are crucial for the reactivity of bare and promoted MnOx systems, owing to positive effects on O2-activation and lattice-oxygen mobility [9–11,19–21,24,28,31,35,37,47,49]. Overall, these evidences document a rough knowledge of active sites, reflecting on a substantial unpredictability of catalyst requirements, since also remarkable effects of preparation method [1–6,16–18,27,29,31,31,32,33,34,37–39,44] and testing conditions [2,31] on the functionality of bare and promoted MnOx systems have been ascertained. Therefore, this study is aimed at shedding light into the genesis and the chemistry of surface manganese sites, shaping the functionality of bare and ceria-promoted MnOx catalysts in the CO oxidation and phenol wet air oxidation (CWAO) model reactions (T, 423 K). Characterization and activity data unveil basic structure-activity relationships highlighting the benchmarks of MnOx catalyst design for environmental applications in gas and liquid phase. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The redox-precipitation technique was applied for the preparation of two series of MxCy materials with different Mn-to-Ce atomic ratio (i.e., x/y) in slightly acidic and basic solution, labelled with “A” and “B” respectively. Namely, the “A” catalysts were prepared by titration in acidic solution (pH, 4.5 ± 0.5) of the Mn(NO3)2 salt with solutions of Ce(NH3)2(NO3)6 and KMnO4 precursors [14,29], while “B” catalysts were obtained by titration in basic environment (pH, 8.0 ± 0.5) of the KMnO4 precursor with solutions of the Mn(NO3)2 and Ce(NO3)3 salts [26,38,39]. After titration, the solids were filtered, washed, dried at 373 K (16 h) and then calcined in air at 673 K (6 h). Codes, composition, and textural properties of the catalysts are summarized in Table 1 , while further details of design and preparation can be found in the App. A of SI. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) analyses were performed to obtain the composition of catalysts. Nitrogen Adsorption Isotherms were acquired by a Micromeritics Instrument ASAP 2010 adsorption device (77 K), after sample degassing at 423 K (12 h). The isotherms were elaborated by the BET and BJH methods to obtain the specific surface area (SA), the pore volume (PV) and the average pore diameter (APD) data. X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained at scan rate of 0.1°⋅ min−1 by a Philips X-Pert diffractometer, using the Ni β-filtered Cu Kα radiation (40 kV; 30 mA). Laser Raman Scattering spectroscopy analyses were performed using a He-Ne laser (λ, 632.8 nm) at a power beam of 30 μW, focused on the sample by a 50× objective at long focal distance over a 1.5 μm diameter spot, with a resolution of 3 cm−1 [14]. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) analyses were performed by a PHILIPS CM12 microscope operated at 200 kV on catalyst samples ultrasonically dispersed in isopropanol and deposited over a thin carbon-film supported on a standard Cu-grid. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained using a Physical Electronics GMBH PHI 5800-01 spectrometer operating with a mono-chromatized Al-Kα radiation (300 W). The BE regions of Mn2p (635−680 eV), Ce3d (870−935 eV) and O1s (525−535 eV) were calibrated using the C1s line (284.8 eV) as reference [14]. Infrared absorption-transmission (IR) spectra were run on a Perkin-Elmer FTIR System 2000 spectrometer equipped with Hg-Cd-Te cryo-detector, with a resolution of 2 cm−1, averaging 100 scans. Catalyst powders were compressed in self-supporting pellets (∼10 mg cm-2) and placed in a conventional IR cell equipped with KBr windows. After a treatment in vacuum (p<5⋅10-4 mbar) at 673 K for 30 min and, then, in O2 (40 mbar) at the same temperature (30 min), the samples were cooled down to 298 K and further outgassed to a residual pressure of 5⋅10-4 mbar. The IR spectra were recorded at 298 K during the interaction with a CO-O2 mixture (pCO , 25 mbar; pCO /pO2 , 1) or with CO2 at increasing pressure (0−25 mbar) and normalized for the specific surface area of the samples. Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) analyses in the range of 293−1073 K of catalyst samples (∼20 mg), untreated and pre-treated in situ in 5% O2/He flow at 673 K (1 h), were carried out in a quartz reactor (i.d., 4 mm), fed with a 5% H2/Ar carrier (60 stp mL⋅ min−1) and heated at the rate of 12 K⋅ min−1. The H2 consumption was monitored by a TCD and normalized for the MnOx content of the catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst testing CO oxidation activity data at 423 K were obtained using the above quartz reactor (wcat, 20 mg) fed with a CO/O2/He mixture (1/1/38) at the rate of 60 stp mL⋅ min−1 (GHSV, 180,000 h−1). Before tests the catalysts were treated in 5% O2/He flow at 423 K, while the reaction stream has been analysed by a QMS as elsewhere described [14,27,29]. Catalytic Wet Air Oxidation (CWAO) of phenol tests were carried out in (semi)batch mode, at a pressure of 1.4 MPa (pO2, 0.9 MPa), using a PTF-lined autoclave (0.25 L) equipped with a magnetic stirrer (∼800 rpm). The reactor was loaded with an aqueous solution (0.15 L) of phenol (1 g/L) and 0.75 g of powdered catalyst (wcat/wPhOH, 5), fed with a continuous O2 flow (0.1 stp L⋅ min−1) and then heated at 423 K. The tests were run for 6 h and the solution was periodically analysed with respect to pH, phenol and total organic carbon (TOC) concentration. Moreover, the mineralization activity (YCO2) was probed by gravimetric analyses of CO2 in the outlet reaction stream [38,39,50], the CO2 space-time-yield (YCO2<15 %) being obtained by the formula (1) s t y = Δ Y C O 2 Δ t ∙ C a t m o l P h e n ∙ w P h e n P M P h e n ∙ 1 w c a t = Δ Y C O 2 Δ t ∙ 0.0128 m o l C O 2 ∙ g c a t - 1 ∙ s - 1 Catalyst stability was evaluated during seven consecutive reaction cycles of six hours, carried out at the end of each run under the same conditions without any intermediate catalyst treatment. 3 RESULTS and DISCUSSION 3.1 Effect of composition on the activity pattern The effects of composition on the gas and liquid phase oxidation activity were comparatively probed by catalytic tests in the CO oxidation and phenol CWAO model reactions (T, 423 K), using tubular continuous-flow [14,29] and stirred batch [38,39] reactors, respectively. The stationary regime of the first implies the full consistency of CO conversion (XCO) and CO2 yield (YCO2) data, while all the catalysts exhibit an unchanging CWAO pattern involving continuous changes of phenol (XPhOH) and TOC (XTOC) concentration, of pH and CO2 yield (YCO2) during 6 h of reaction time (Fig. S3 of SI). These features mirror a classic L-H reaction path, limited by the surface oxidation step (r.d.s.), since a fast adsorption of the substrate accounts for XPhOH and XTOC while the slow oxidation of adsorbed species causes the side-formation of C1-C2 acidic intermediates, leading to progressive decrease of XTOC and pH, and build-up of C-deposits on the catalyst surface [37–40,50]. These evidences substantiate the reliability of CO2 yield data to probe the oxidative functionality in liquid phase (see Tab. S1 of SI). On this account, Fig. 1 A shows that the most effective M1C1(A) catalyst prompts a full conversion of phenol and TOC in ca. 15 min, attaining an almost complete carbon mineralization (YCO2∼90 %) in 6 h. The remarkable water purification efficiency of the M1C1 catalyst is also evident from a slight formation of C1-C2 acids, accounting for final residual TOC traces (XTOC, 95 %) and a pH value of ca. 5 [39,50]. Consequence of an almost complete substrate mineralization hindering the growth of carbonaceous deposits and the consequent fouling of active sites [39,50], the M1C1(A) catalyst features also a substantial stability during seven reusability tests (Fig. 1B), as indicated by: i) a full phenol removal (XPhOH, 100 %) throughout all the reaction cycles; ii) a TOC abatement (XTOC) lowering from 95 to 70 % after four cycles and keeping unchanged thereafter; and iii) a CO2 yield (YCO2) decreasing from 90 to 45 % during the first five cycles, levelling off thereafter. A minor influence of the preparation method is evident from the similar activity pattern of the M1C1(B) catalyst (YCO2∼85 %), while the M1C3(A) sample ensures a slightly lower CO2 yield (YCO2∼80 %) higher than M3C1(A) and M5C1(A) ones (YCO2∼65 %) (Fig. S3 of SI). Finally, slow rate of phenol and TOC removal (∼1 h) and, mostly, final YCO2 (45 %), XTOC (80 %) and pH (∼3) values signal the worst CWAO performance of the bare M(A) catalyst. Thus, the final YCO2 values (6 h) depict a volcano-shaped trend with Mn loading (Fig. 2 ), indicating an optimum catalyst composition including similar amount of manganese and cerium atoms (i.e., M1C1) [26,40]. Despite a very short contact time (GHSV, 180,000 h−1), YCO2 values between 10 and 30 % indicate that bare and promoted catalysts also feature a remarkable activity in the CO oxidation (Tab. S1 of SI). However, contrarily to what observed in the CWAO of phenol, the M(A) sample features the highest activity, while the M1C1(B), M1C1(A), M3C1(A) and M5C1(A) catalysts have similar performances, better than the M1C3(A) sample [14,29]. The catalyst stability has been previously assessed [14,27], while YCO2 data depict a peculiar increasing trend with Mn loading that, compared with that in the CWAO of phenol (Fig. 2), discloses a strong influence of the reaction environment on the functionality of bare and promoted MnOx catalysts. 3.2 Effect of composition and preparation method on catalyst structure As a rule, bare oxides and composite MnCeOx materials feature type-IV adsorption-desorption isotherms typical of mesoporous materials, while the desorption branches depict type H2-H3 hysteresis loops, depending on pore size distribution (Fig. S4 of SI). In particular, the composite MnCeOx systems are characterised by specific surface area (SSA) values larger than each oxide component, showing a maximum for χMn in-between 0.25 (M1C3) and 0.5 (M1C1) that is diagnostic of synergistic structural effects of the oxide phases (Fig. S5 of SI). In particular, the SSA of the pristine M(B) and C(B) systems is equal to 61 and 115 m2/g respectively, ranging between 115 (M3C1(B)) and 167 m2/g (M1C3(B)) for the composite MnCeOx catalysts (Table 1). Although the synthesis in acidic solution favours a larger surface development (Table 1), a trend similar to “B” counterparts is observed also for “A” catalysts (Fig. S5 of SI). Furthermore, both series of catalysts are characterized by similar pore volume (PV), although the average pore diameter (APD) of “A” catalysts keeps unchanged (24-3124−31 nm) growing with Mn loading (4−24 nm) for “B” ones (Table 1). According to literature data (Fig. S4 of SI), such findings show a decisive influence of the preparation method on catalyst surface area while an unchanging composition-effect is the result of a strong oxide synergism, deeply affecting the structure of MnCeOx materials [19,30–37,40]. Indeed, the XRD patterns of promoted “B” catalysts feature two broad signals in the range of 20−80°, being diagnostic of a negligible crystalline order of both CeO2 and MnOx phases (Fig. 3 ). In particular, TEM images show that the M1C1(B) sample consists of aggregates of tiny (<10 nm) particles (Fig. 4 A), including very irregular and defective ceria clusters (yellow circles) stuck by an amorphous array of the MnOx phase (Fig. 4B). Despite broad peaks at 28.5, 33, 47.5 and 56.5° denote some higher crystallinity of catalysts obtained in acidic solution (Fig. 3), the M1C1(A) catalyst features morphology (Fig. 4C) and structure (Fig. 4D) similar to the M1C1(B) counterpart. The fading of ceria lines occurring at higher Mn loading renders similar the patterns of M3C1 catalysts, while a weak reflex at ca. 37° reveals an incipient crystallization of the MnO2 phase in the M3C1(A) sample. This is more evident for the M5C1(A) catalyst showing, in fact, nanofibers/nanorods morphology (Fig. 4E) and a “layered” structure (red circles) of catalyst particles (Fig. 4F), typical of MnO2 materials. Consistent with this trend, the XRD pattern of the pristine M(A) sample matches that of α-MnO2 polymorphs with tunnel-structure including K+ ions (JCPDS 44-0141), while the genesis in alkaline solution accounts for the birnessite-type arrangement of the M(B) sample (JCPDS 18-0802). In fact, the potassium content of the pristine M(A) and M(B) samples (Table 1) matches the chemical composition of the α-MnO2 (K0.12MnO2) and δ-MnO2 (K0.23MnO2) phases, respectively [9,16,22,41,47–50]. Further clues on the short-range structure and dispersion of the oxide phases are available from Raman (Fig. 5 A) and XPS (Fig. 5B) analyses. In particular, the Raman spectrum of the bare M(A) sample shows three Raman signals at 187, 584 and 635 cm−1 that are characteristic of α-MnO2 and/or cryptomelane polymorphs [5,14,16,22,43,49,51], while the lack of the first peak and the slight shifts of the others at higher wavenumbers (575 cm-1 and 649 cm-1) substantiate the low crystallinity of MnO2 domains in the M3C1(A) and M5C1(A) samples [32,37]. However, such Raman features can be also related to a birnessite-type arrangement of MnO2 domains (Fig. 4F) [37], since cerium ions likely hinder the layer-to-tunnel transition from “δ” to α-MnO2 phase [19,21,52–54]. Finally, the absence of Mn-O bonds (620−660 cm−1) and F 2g cerianite (460 cm-1) fingerprints reveals the lack of any short-range order in both M1C3(A) and M1C1(A) samples (Fig. 5A) [55]. These data suggest that the redox interactions of the precursors (see App. A of SI) prompt the formation of nanostructures with high inter-dispersion of the oxide species, as confirmed by the homogeneous concentration profile of Mn and Ce atoms across catalyst particles, irrespective of the preparation method (Fig. 5B). 3.3 Speciation and reduction pattern of the active phase The TPR analysis discloses a high reducibility of bare and promoted catalysts in the range of 373−723 K, mostly due to the redox functionality of the MnOx phase (Fig. 6 ). Indeed, the TPR pattern of the bare M(A) sample shows two resolved peaks centred at 565 and 613 K, in a ratio of 2:1, arising from the stepwise reduction of MnO2 domains to Mn3O4 and MnO, respectively. While a small peak at 773 K and the subsequent H2 consumption account for the poor reducibility of ceria at the surface and in the bulk, respectively (Fig. 6A) [23,27,30,33,38]. Consistent with such patterns, the M1C3(A) and M1C1(A) catalysts feature a sharp TM1 peak due to the reduction of surface Mn(IV) atoms to Mn(II), while the TM2 peak of Mn2O3-Mn3O4 species is almost absent [14,23,27,56]. In fact, a lowering intensity with Mn loading proves that the shoulder at 660 K (TM3) is due to an early reduction of surface Ce(IV) ions, owing to the promoting effect of the MnOx phase on ceria lattice oxygen mobility [19,27,30,33,39,40]. The lack of the sharp TM1 maximum reflects lower amounts of Mn(IV) atoms in the M1C3(B) and M1C1(B) catalysts, although the same initial reduction rate of M3C1 samples indicates that the concentration of Mn(IV) atoms grows with Mn loading, regardless of the preparation method (Fig. 6B). Further, the upward TM1 shift and the growth of TM2 peak observed at high Mn loading (Fig. 6) reflect the progressive clustering of Mn(IV) atoms into MnO2 domains, while minor changes in the onset reduction (Tab. S2 of SI) rule out any chemical effect of ceria on the reactivity of surface Mn(IV) atoms. Although the TPR profiles shed light into the redox properties of Mn(IV) atoms, the concomitant reduction of ceria determines unsystematic H2 consumption data (Tab. S2 of SI) concealing further clues on the speciation of the active MnOx phase. Thus, a deconvolution analysis of the XPS Mn 2p peaks (see App. B of SI) was applied to shed light into the surface chemistry of the studied systems. Shown in Fig. 7 A, such data indicate that: • Mn(II) atoms (25–35 %) abound at low Mn loading (χMn≤0.5), decaying at trace levels thereafter (2–6 %); • large extents of Mn(III) atoms (30–40 %) are present on the promoted catalysts, although a significant fraction (∼15 %) is also present on the pristine M(A) sample; • Mn(IV) atoms (60–85 %) prevail at high Mn loading (χMn>0.5). Hence, beside to the remarkable effects on texture, structure and oxide dispersion, XPS data unveil a strong influence of ceria matrix on the chemistry of the MnOx phase, consistent with the formation of solid-solution structures [26–28,30–40,46–48]. In this respect, the incorporation of Mn(III) (d, 0.65 Å) and Mn(IV) (d, 0.58 Å) ions into ceria lattice should be hindered by size compatibility issues, while larger Mn(II) ions (d, 0.83 Å) can replace Ce(IV) ones (d, 0.97 Å) up to a maximum cationic content of 15 % (i.e., Mn(II)/(Mn + Ce)), forming substitutional solid-solution structures [36,48]. Percentages of Mn(II) atoms in the M1C3(A) and M1C1(A) catalysts (Fig. 7A) corresponding to cationic contents of 10 and 14 % respectively, support theoretical predictions [36,48]. The replacement implies the formation of O-vacancies for charge balance that lower the stability of ceria lattice, promoting the reduction of cerium atoms (Fig. 6). Quantitative TPR (Tab. S2 of SI) prove the key-role of Mn(II) ions on the early reduction of ceria, since the H2 consumption exceeding that expected from the Mn AON provided by the XPS analysis (see Fig. S7 of SI) corresponds to amounts of reduced Ce(IV) ions following a trend analogous to the abundance of Mn(II) atoms in the various catalysts (Fig. 7B). Moreover, the Mn(II)/Ce(IV) replacement determines a lattice-shrinking effect that forces the stabilization of Mn(III) atoms onto the surface defective positions of ceria particles [36,44], while Mn(IV) atoms form MnO2 over-layers (e.g., patches, islands) evolving into crystalline domains at high Mn loading. 3.4 Active sites Although the high reactivity of MnCeOx catalysts depends on solid solution sites, the stability of Mn(II) atoms under reducing conditions hinders their fingerprint in the TPR pattern of the untreated samples (Fig. 6). In fact, a pretreatment in O2 (673 K) causes the appearance of a new peak, labeled as TM0 (Fig. 8 ), accounting for a proportionally larger H2 consumption (Tab. S2 of SI). In particular, the amplitude of the TM0 peak decreases systematically with Mn loading (Fig. 8A), being comparable for M1C1(A) and M1C1(B) catalysts (Fig. 8B). Thus, low temperature maximum (∼423 K), being diagnostic of a strong oxidizing power, and a trend similar to the percentage of Mn(II) atoms (Fig. 7A) disclose that the TM0 component is produced by solid solution sites. In fact, it is likely that the dehydration of Mn(II)/O-vacancy centers favors the O2 adsorption, producing very reactive surface oxygen-species (i.e., O2 −, O2 =) yielding the TM0 peak [30]. On this account, a comparative IR study of the interactions of M5C1(A), M1C1(A) and M1C3(A) catalysts with a CO-O2 mixture (Fig. 9 A) and CO2 (Fig. 9B) provides further evidence of the functionality of Mn(II) and surface Mn(IV) sites. In particular, the spectra of the catalysts contacted for 30 min with the CO-O2 (1/1) mixture show complex envelopes of bands in the range of 1700−800 cm-1 (Fig. 9A). Although the intensity depends on the material, the absorption features are very similar with few exceptions. In fact, in the light of literature data [30,31,57–59] and of the CO2 adsorption spectra (v. infra), all the absorption bands can be assigned to surface carbonate species. Moreover, the spectral features are much like those of carbonates adsorbed on MnOx materials [30,31,58], rather than to carbonate species in interaction with CeO2 [31,59]. Thus, the spectra can be rationalized as follows: • the bands at 1608, 1398 and 1216 cm−1 are assigned to the ν(CO), ν(CO) and δ(OH) modes of hydrogen-carbonates, respectively; • the bands at 1510, 1327 and 1050 cm−1 are due to the ν asym(OCO), ν sym(OCO) and ν(CO) modes of monodentate-carbonates, respectively; • the bands at 1576, 1303 and 1050 cm−1 are assigned to ν(CO), ν asym(OCO) and ν sym(OCO) modes of bidentate-carbonates, respectively. The components at 1616 and 1272 cm−1, more evident for the M5C1-RM4 sample, are also attributable to the ν(CO) and ν asym(OCO) modes of bidentate-carbonates. Further, the band at 857 cm−1 can be related to the δ(OCO) mode of both monodentate and bidentate carbonates. Finally, a small amount of bridged carbonates, producing bands at 1680 and 1248 cm−1 (ν(CO) and ν asym(OCO) modes, respectively, being the third ν sym(OCO) mode in the envelope at ∼1050 cm−1) is observed only for M5C1(A). It is likely that the latter species could form on poorly crystalline MnO2 domains of the M5C1(A) catalyst [60,61]. On the other hand, the amorphous character of the MnOx phase in the three catalysts accounts for the heterogeneity of surface sites evidenced by the formation of monodentate and two families of bidentate carbonates. Formed by the surface interactions of CO and O2 and by the chemisorption of the CO2 product, these confirm the ability of the three catalysts to drive the CO oxidation at 298 K [14,29–31,43,44,61]. However, considering that the intensity of adsorbed carbonate species rises in the order M5C1(A) < M1C1(A) < M1C3(A), the occurrence of larger carbonate amounts at low Mn loading seems contradictory. This apparent inconsistency is explained by the spectral features of the M5C1(A) catalyst during CO2 adsorption at increasing pressure, which are compared with the spectrum obtained in CO-O2 after 30 min (Fig. 10 B). This shows a much higher intensity of the carbonate bands when dosing CO2, suggesting that the intensity of the pattern in the latter case is not limited by the availability of adsorption sites, rather depending on the amount of CO2 produced by the CO oxidation. In other words, the intensity of the surface carbonates bands reflects the CO oxidation activity at 298 K [14,29,31]. Matching the intensity of the TM0 peak (Fig. 8A), thus, IR data substantiate a stronger CO oxidation activity of Mn(II) sites, which are prevalent on M1C3(A) and M1C1(A) catalysts. 3.5 Structure-activity relationships Consistent with the YCO2 trend in Fig. 1, kinetic data (Tab. S1 of SI) indicate an unchanging CO oxidation activity scale referred to both weight (space-time-yield, STY) and catalyst surface area (specific surface-time-yield, ssty) M(A) > M1C1(A) ≈ M1C1(B) ≈ M5C1(A) > M1C3(A). First evidence of higher gas phase activity of the pristine α-MnO2 system than composite MnCeOx catalysts [19,26,31–34,36,40], this depends on the effectiveness of the synthesis route to generate MnO2 nanoparticles with large surface exposure of Mn(IV) active sites [14,23,26,29,56]. Despite much lower surface availability of Mn(IV) sites (Fig. 7A), however, the similar activity of M1C1(A), M1C1(B) and M5C1(A) catalysts suggests that surface Mn(II)/Mn(III) atoms enhance the oxidative strength of composite systems, determining a very different activity scale in the CWAO of phenol (Tab. S1 of SI): M1C1(A) ≈ M1C1(B) > M1C3(A) > M5C1(A) > M(A). These findings indicate a decisive influence of the reaction environment on the catalytic activity that depends on the functionality of the various surface sites, as unveiled by the comparison of the CO2 MnOx-site (Fig. 10A) and surface (Fig. 10B) time-yield (Tab. S1 of SI) with the percentage (Fig. 10A’) and surface abundance (Fig. 10B’) of manganese atoms. Although the MnOx-site time-yield values (sty MnOx) in the CWAO of phenol are lower by more than one order of magnitude (5⋅10−5-4⋅10-4 s-1) than in the CO oxidation (1.3⋅10-3-3.5⋅10-3 s-1), both data sets describe analogous decreasing trends with Mn loading (Fig. 10A), mirroring the fraction of Mn(II) atoms of the various catalysts (Fig. 10A’). Similarly to that found for the NO decomposition reaction [36], these structure-activity relationships prove the decisive role of Mn(II) solid solution centres on the reactivity of MnCeOx systems. Indeed, the surface abundance of Mn(II) sites (Fig. 10B’) accounts for the highest surface specific activity (i.e., ssty) of M1C1 catalysts in the CWAO of phenol, also explaining ssty values comparing to M3C1(A) and M5C1(A) catalysts in the CO oxidation (Fig. 10B). At variance, similar exponential-rising trends prove that surface Mn(IV) sites (Fig. 10B’) determine the superior surface CO oxidation activity of the pristine α-MnO2 sample (Fig. 10B) [62]. However, a stronger negative effect of the aqueous environment on the functionality of Mn(IV) active sites is evident from the steeper decrease of the sty MnOx in the CWAO of phenol at high Mn loading (Fig. 10A) [13,31]. Notably, these findings also explain the best performance of the M(A) catalyst in the non-aqueous green selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol [23,63], while the lack of correlations infers a negligible role of Mn(III) atoms, if any, on the reactivity pattern of the studied systems (Fig. 10). 4 Conclusions Nanostructured MnO2 and MnCeOx catalysts were prepared via different protocols of the redox-precipitation technique to assess nature, genesis and functionality of surface active sites. Large surface area and very high oxide dispersion promote the incorporation of Mn(II) ions into ceria solid-solution structures leading to the formation of surface oxygen-vacancies. Surface Mn(IV) and solid solution Mn(II)/O-vacancy are the active sites shaping the oxidative functionality of bare and ceria-promoted MnOx catalysts in gas and liquid phase. Oxygen adsorption onto substitutional solid solution Mn(II)/O-vacancy centres generates very reactive O2-species boosting the performance of MnCeOx catalysts in the CWAO of phenol. Large availability of easily reducible Mn(IV) active sites determines the superior efficiency of the pristine MnO2 system in the gas phase CO oxidation. Preparation method and end application are benchmarks of MnOx catalyst design for environmental applications in gas and liquid phase. coredata.dc:description: Bare and ceria-promoted MnOx catalysts (0 ≤ χMn≤1) were prepared by redox-precipitation reactions of Mn(VII), Mn(II) and Ce(III) or Ce(IV) precursors in slightly acidic (pH, 4.5) or basic (pH, 8.0) environment to assess genesis, nature, and functionality of surface active sites. Both synthesis protocols yield nanostructured materials with large surface area and exposure of Mn sites, featuring high activity in the CO oxidation and the phenol wet-air-oxidation (CWAO) model reactions (T, 423 K). High oxide dispersion prompts an extensive incorporation of Mn(II) ions into ceria substitutional solid-solution structures, forming oxygen-vacancies with stronger oxidation activity than surface Mn(IV) sites. Basic structure-activity relationships indicate that the superior CO oxidation performance of the pristine α-MnO2 system relies on large exposure of very reducible Mn(IV) active sites, while O2-adsorption onto Mn(II)/O-vacancy active centres generates very reactive surface oxygen-species boosting the efficiency of composite MnCeOx catalysts in the CWAO of phenol.
coredata.dc:title: Tailoring manganese oxide catalysts for the total oxidation of pollutants in gas and liquid phase
